Ebola virus (EBOV) is an enveloped negative-sense single-stranded RNA virus that belongs to the genus Ebolavirus of the family Filoviridae. EBOV is introduced into humans from wild animals and spreads in the human population through person-to-person transmission. Ebola virus disease (EVD), known as Ebola hemorrhagic fever, has a high fatality rate, ranging from 25 to 90% in past outbreaks. Through a systematic screen of FDA-approved drugs, niclosamide was identified as one of the most potent EBOV inhibitors with an EC 50 value of 1.5 Î¼M, although its in vivo efficacy has not yet been evaluated in animal models.
